byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald contributed reporting from Washington, and Kantaro Suzuki from Tokyo.

abstract: Japanese citizens' group that has been testing for radiation levels in Tokyo in conjunction with a respected nuclear research center has found potentially harmful levels of radioactivity in more than 20 spots in and around the city; the findings have raised new concerns about how far the contamination from the devastated Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant has spread, and the government's handling of the situation.
snippet: Radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant may have spread to places where Japan’s government hasn’t even thought to look.
lead_paragraph: Radiation from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear power plant may have spread to places where Japan’s government hasn’t even thought to look.

headline.main: Citizens’ Testing Finds 20 Hot Spots Around Tokyo
headline.print_headline: Citizens’ Testing Finds 20 Radioactive Hot Spots Around Tokyo
headline.seo: Radioactive Hot Spots in Tokyo Raise Fears of Wider Contamination
